title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-may-10-14-1996-1971-1921
story: A BID to ban booze in a North Berwick park was being proposed, reported the East Lothian Courier on May , .An alcohol exclusion zone could be created in North Berwick as part of a joint police and community initiative to curb underage drinking in town.Plans are underway to ban alcohol from the Lodge Grounds public park ndash a popular haunt for teeny tipplers.A similar scheme is already operating in several streets in Prestonpans ndash the first town in the district to introduce no-go areas for public drinking ndash and police in North Berwick are keen to follow suit.They hope to get the backing of nearby residents and the local community council before taking the idea to East Lothian Licensing Board for formal approval.The matter was discussed at the monthly meeting of North Berwick Community Council on Tuesday.Sergeant Alistair McIntyre warned that banning the drinking of alcohol in the park could push the underage tipplers to other areas of the town, possibly the harbour.FIVE generations of the same family were in attendance at a baptism in Dunbar, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .When baby Kathleen Lorimer was baptised in Dunbar Parish Church, her father, grandfather, great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were there to watch the ceremony.The occasion marked the first time the five generations had gathered together.Baby Kathleen Vanessa is the daughter of Mr Tom Lorimerand his we, Avril.Her grandfather, Mr John Lorimer, gardener, and his we Chris, were there, as were her great-grandfather, Mr Tom Lorimer, a foreman with North Berwick Town Council, and his we Jean.The eldest member of the party was -year-old Mr John Lorimer.TWO men appeared in court after stealing planks of wood from a mine, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .On Friday, at Haddington Sherf Court, Peter Devannah, labourer and John Devannah, miner, both from Tranent, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday rd April, stolen four planks of wood from the pithead of Bankton colliery.The Fiscal said that the accused and another man were seen carrying planks up the railway line from the pit.When the police followed them, they made off.The accused were overtaken, but the third man escaped.They were taken back to the pit and admitted having stolen the wood.They were each fined s.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-14-great-wood-caledon
story: FINN walked by the side of Lochan nam Arm, peering into the water in his search for Robert the Brucersquos sword. Then, something caught his eye.He ran to Izzy: ldquoAunty, aunty, look what I found!He was holding a scarf.ldquoIt was hanging on a tree over there, he said.It was a short neck scarf, with Celtic interlacing design it looked new and unworn, possibly even handmade.ldquoI really love it aunty, can I keep it Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoI dunno, Finn, someone may have dropped it and another person found it and placed it on the tree to keep it safe. Perhaps one of those walkers earlier. Maybe they will come back and look for it Finn wasnrsquot even half listening. He put the scarf on and rushed to the loch side to look at his reflection.ldquoIt would be safer round my neck surely  he called out.As he arranged the scarf, a folded piece of paper fell to the ground and landed by Finnrsquos feet. He picked it up, unfolded it and ran to Izzy, very excited.ldquoLook, the scarf is for me! he exclaimed.A worried look came over Izzyrsquos face as Finn handed her the piece of paper. There were beautully drawn Celtic designs, with images of what looked like faeries hiding in a wood.There was also a sleeping dragon curled round a heart shape in which there was handwriting: ldquoIf you have found me, and you like me, then Irsquom yours. Keep me safe, until itrsquos time to give me away.Izzy looked at Finn, nodded and smiled. ldquoSo it seems.ldquoI will never give this away! he insisted. He looked around at the trees and ed the gaze to his aunt.ldquoMaybe yoursquore right, aunty, maybe fairies do exist after all, at least here we are in the Highlands after all.He thought for a moment. ldquoOr maybe itrsquos just someone kind who likes to give presents.Finn headed back to the tree where hersquod found the scarf. He arranged twigs and broken bits of heather on the ground next to the tree and beckoned his aunt to come see.She looked down at what hersquod done. She didnrsquot immediately see it, but then realised that the twigs and heather formed letters.He carefully read it: ldquoThank you.ldquoThatrsquos lovely Finn, whoever left the scarf will see this and be very happy, Irsquom sure of it.Izzy looked up to the sky. The predicted rain was going to hold off.ldquoFinn, she said hesitantly, ldquowould you be up for a bit of an adventure ldquoYou mean a walk, donrsquot you ldquoKind of, aye, but this is to a place I have never been before, although Irsquove often seen it from a distance.ldquoHow far  asked Finn.Izzy pointed: ldquoJust there, where those old trees are. Itrsquos a small remnant of the old Caledonian forest, Irsquove often wanted to visit it but have never had the opportunity. Itrsquos not so far, but it might be a bit dficult to reach, Irsquove never explored it before.Finn wasnrsquot sure.Izzy helped him decide: ldquoIt might have a connection to the original Merlin.That sold it to him.ldquoWell, I have my boots, he smiled, ldquocan I lead the way So they set off in the direction of Coille Coire Chuic, a small remnant of the ancient Caledonian forest. Izzy let Finn decide on the route and as they neared the wood they arrived at the River Cononish. There was no obvious and safe way to cross, but Izzy was sure there was a small bridge downriver.The route got increasingly boggy and Izzy suspected Finn may want to give up, but instead he took the role of leader seriously and carefully planned each step, identying dryer patches and helping his aunt. They made slow progress, but with much hilarity as they balanced on small tufts of dry land surrounded by bog myrtle.Finn paused and listened. The noise of a waterfall could be heard ahead and he aimed for it. Izzy lagged behind to take in the beauty of the heather, which carpeted the ground with a blaze of purple and pink. The old Scots pines on the other side of the river looked magnicent, framed by the mountains beyond.She caught up with Finn, who was sitting on a rock watching the waterfall. It cascaded into a hidden pool, where the water twirled and bubbled asin a giant cauldron. Scots pine trees stood guard on the edge of it, one growing precariously from the overhanging rocks, its trunk curving upwards so its higher branches reached the sunlight. A gnarled rowan with vivid berries grew from the rocks on the other side, while on the opposite bank birch trees clung onto the steep side of the river, bent over like weeping willows.Finn wanted to sit awhile and so Izzy took it as an opportunity to make a brew for them both. He was beginning to understand that using her small camping stove was an important ritual for his aunt: the hissing sound, the waiting, the trail of steam, the anticipation it made a warm feeling, turned a wild place into home.They sipped tea together and shared well-earned snacks. Finn waited, expecting his aunt to tell a story. Finally, she did.ldquoSee that giant boulder over there, Finn, it was dropped by the giants who sculpted this land many years ago.ldquoLike with Samsonrsquos stone we saw Izzy nodded.Finn raised a cynical eyebrow and half a smile.ldquoHuge giants, Finn, a race called the Fomorians. The legend says they emerged from the sea long ago ndash grotesque troll-like creatures, incredibly powerful and cruel. Two of them made Rannoch Moor their home and they terrorised the people for miles around, destroying homes and taking livestock.ldquoNobody knew what to do, even the bravest and best warriors were defeated by them, ripped apart without mercy. Then a young lad about your age had his home destroyed by one of the giants, and in his grief he decided to rid the land of them.ldquoBut how could he do thateven the best warriors couldnrsquot Izzy gave him a wry smile, which he knew meant that was a good question and that she was just about to answer it.ldquoThe lad was wise. He had noticed how the two giants argued with each other about who was the stronger.ldquoSo he got them to fight each other ldquoKind of, he persuaded them to have a competition to see who could throw a stone furthest. They began hurling bigger and bigger stones, then they tore chunks of rock off the mountain sides. Soon the land was littered with boulders, and after three days the two giants were utterly exhausted.ldquoThen the young lad told one of the giants he had won, for he knew this would cause a fight. And so it did.ldquoThe giants fought each other with fury, using up what energy they had left. Finally, one gave the other a fatal blow, but it was the last thing he did, as he collapsed with total exhaustion.ldquoThey had killed each other ldquoYes, smiled Izzy, filling her cup with more tea and raising it. ldquoThatrsquos why the land around here is littered with all these huge stones.ldquoI know giants are mythological, aunty.Izzy sipped some tea.ldquoDepends what kind of giants you mean.Finn looked at the boulder.ldquoThe next tale is the gt of the sun, continued Izzy.ldquoAfter the death of the giants the land was bathed in sunshine, bringing new le.It became a green world, grass and plants grew, then trees arrived. The ancestors of this tree were first to arrive, she pointed to the nearby silver birch.ldquoOthers followed: the rowan, the aspen, alder and even oak. But it was these trees which made the forest canopy: Scots pines, also called Caledonian pines, an old name given to them by the Romans. Arenrsquot they a beautul tree Finn peered at the Scots pines around them.ldquoCreatures filled the forest with their songs, their roars, their grunting and howling the birds, bears, wolves, elk, deer and boar. Seven thousand years ago, where we sit we would have been amidst the Caledonian forest in its prime. Those trees over there are the descendants of that forest. If you sit with them and feel their presence, they will tell you their stories.Finn chuckled at his aunt, then explained why. ldquoYou are like Yoda! He defensively held up his hands to explain: ldquoNot the way you look, I mean the way you speak about things.Finn was a Star Wars fan. He had all three films on video at home and knew much of the dialogue by heart. He spoke to Izzy, mimicking Yodarsquos voice: ldquoSearch the force, le creates it, makes it grow, its energy surrounds us and binds us, luminous beings are we. Finn gently pinched Izzy on the shoulder, saying: ldquoNot this crude matter. You must feel the force around you, the tree, the rock, everywhere.Izzy laughed out loud, feeling rather flattered to be compared to one of Finnrsquos screen heroes. She thanked him for the compliment.Finn looked over at the old Scots pines on the other side of the river. He knew his aunt wanted to reach them and they were tantalisingly close, yet the river was too dangerous to cross.ldquoLetrsquos find a way to get there, he ventured.They packed up and followed the river, eventually finding a place to cross. They sat amidst the flowering heather under the canopy of old trees, near a clearing so a light breeze kept the midges at bay. As promised, Izzy spun legends of Merlin, but also other tales connected to the ancient forest: of Lailoken, the Picts and St Columba, and the sad tale of the last wolf. Finn added tales of his own, about Jedi Knights and what he could remember of the story of Tam Linn. The forest was both their theatre and audience. But there was a sense of melancholy in this wood, for something was missing: it was bereft of young trees. The old pines were missing their children.The walk back was much quicker and they arrived back at the car tired, but with a sense of achievement. It felt asthey had been in a dferent world.ldquoCan we camp tonight aunty  asked Finn. ldquoAnd have a campfire like the first night ldquoLetrsquos see how the weather holds and how we feel later, she replied, keeping options open.Food was now a priority and Izzy was keen to get away from the busyness of Tyndrum. Soon they were on their way, heading for Loch Tulla, where she planned to make their tea. She knew Ewen would already be at the Bridge of Orchy. What she didnrsquot know was his mum was with him, Finnrsquos grandmother, whom Finn had loved so much.She was waiting with her son in his car, literally trembling with emotion, desperate to see her beloved grandson, whom she hadnrsquot seen for more than four and a half years.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, , ,  and .

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-later-month-work-overhead-lines
story: Roadworks on the A, between the Thistly Cross and Abbotsview junctions, mean that the road will be closed from pm on May  until am the following day.A spokesman for Bear Scotland confirmed that work was being carried out by Keltbray on behalf of ScottishPower.He said that Keltbray had produced a statement, which reads: ldquoKeltbray, on behalf of ScottishPower, are carrying out essential work on a section of overhead lines between May  at pm to May  at am which will result in the closure of a section of the A.ldquoThis will include work on the high voltage and low voltage networks, changing electricity poles and overhead power cables.ldquoWe are replacing and refurbishing equipment which is coming to the end of its serviceable le, which is essential works to make sure we maintain a good quality of supply for our customers.ldquoA ersion route will be in place.ldquoAccess for emergency vehicles will be maintained at all times.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: historic-dunbar-methodist-church-saved-public-use
story: Dunbar Methodist Church ndash the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland ndash dates back to .However, in , the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged and began meeting at the latter.The Victoria Street building was later sold, with developer Monkscroft Properties Limited keen to ensure that ldquothe building remained in use as a public space and as an asset for the community of Dunbar.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department has given the go-ahead to change the building into a venue for weddings, s and community use.Ewan McIntyre, who is behind the scheme, was delighted to see progress being made.He said: ldquoThe best reason to buy the building was to make sure it did not get turned into housing. It is part of the fabric of Dunbar.Minimal changes are planned for the building, with replacement steps outside.The main church space has capacity for about  people for worship, with the developers looking to host ldquosmall and intimate weddings, with a reduced capacity of up to  people seated for lunch or dinner and up to  people in total for ceremonies and celebrations.Stained glass windows have been repaired, while other decoration has been completed inside the building.Members of the public will get the chance to look around the venue on May  and  at an open door event.However, the proposals did not win favour with everyone in the town.The planning department received three letters objecting to the plans, with concerns that there would be loud music played at the venue, disturbance with people congregating before, during and after events, and worries about where people attending events would park their cars.During the planning process, the applicants highlighted ldquorelationships with neighbours are crucial to the success of the venue and the utmost care will be given to managing guests and noise.Dunbarrsquos community council was among those who backed the proposals when they were first lodged with the local authority in summer last year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was pleased the scheme was progressing.She highlighted that the building was not listed and it could have been demolished or transformed to make way for housing.She was pleased the building would remain in community use.Mrs Swan said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled.ldquoI know that the Methodist church building, when it was a place of worship and dwindling congregation, was an uphill struggle to keep the building in good repair.ldquoIt is fantastic that it has got a new owner and wonderful it is being kept as a place of public assembly.

title: tranent-fundraiser-taking-two-double-marathons-walk-walk
story: Margaret MacLeod, , took up marathon running at the age of , and has now completed six official Walk The Walk lsquoOver The Moonrsquo events, which see participants complete  miles in less than  hours.While walkers of the virtual Over The Moon this year are being given a longer, -hour time limit, Margaret has decided to push herself to stay within  hours.The Tranent resident, who will be completing the virtual event on Saturday, said: ldquoItrsquos a huge challenge.ldquoI can walk a marathon in just under six hoursIrsquom really pushing it, and I can run one in just under five itrsquos like running a marathon at your top speed the whole time.Last year, the Walk The Walk fundraiser was cancelled entirely and this yearrsquos has been forced to go virtual, due to Covid ndash but that hasnrsquot stopped the intrepid Winton Close resident, who last year walked  laps of her house for the challenge.She said of this yearrsquos event: ldquoI thoughtI did laps nearby, I could get people to come and walk a lap with me.ldquoAnd before I knew it, I had a wee team!Margaret, a receptionist in the investment industry by day, will be joined on her double marathon journey round the .-mile route by  dferent friends, who will each complete a lap of the route with her.This year, the theme of the event is lsquoOut Of This Worldrsquo, which would usually be illustrated by participantsrsquo decorated bras. But, says Margaret, she is ldquothe worst sewer ever.She told the Courier: ldquoI have no imagination so my bra has just got a wee bit of fringing and some wee glitzy bits. Itrsquos just glammed.And Margaretrsquos two adult sons have mixed feelings about their inspirational mumrsquos athletic achievements. While one ran with her for her first marathon ndash ldquoa challenge for my th birthday according to Margaret ndash the other is not quite as hands-on.She said: ldquoMy younger one ran with me dressed as Elsa from Frozen, so hersquos extremely supportive but the older one just grunts at me: lsquoGood on you, mum.rsquoBut Margaret is pushing ahead with her challenge ndash inspired and supported, she says, by Haddington Running Club ndash despite her own reservations about walking in her bra in daylight.She said: ldquoIrsquom putting myself out there for breast cancer. Irsquom not entirely comfortable with it, anditrsquos raining or cold itrsquos going to be horrendous, but people go through a hell of a lot worse than what Irsquoll be going through.While this weekrsquos fundraiser will be part of the London event, Margaret plans to do the whole thing again on June  for the Edinburgh arm of the charity.An intrepid Margaret said: ldquoThere are going to be a lot of people maybe wondering whatrsquos going on!More information on Walk The Walk can be found at walkthewalk.orgTo donate to Margaretrsquos fundraiser, see walkthewalk.enthuse pf margaret-macleod-d-cd

title: east-lothian-council-midlothian-council-dalkeith-custody-ends
story: Police Scotland has revealed plans to stop staffing the cells at the station, making it an lsquoancillaryrsquo centre which will only be used during major events or as back-up.The move will mean people arrested in East Lothian and Midlothian, who would have been taken into custody in the Midlothian station now face being transported to St Leonardrsquosin Edinburgh for lock-up.A meeting of East Lothianrsquos Police, Fire and Community Safety Scrutiny Committee, was told that the proposals would free up two additional local police officers for the county.However, concerns were raised by councillors about the additional journey time it would take for officers to transport people in custody to the Edinburgh station.Suzie Mertes, from Police Scotlandrsquos Criminal Justice Services ision, said that the number of people being taken into custody in Scotland had halved from , to , in recent timesand changes were being made as part of an annual review.She told the committee that providing custody services at St Leonardrsquos would be better for prisoners who might be vulnerable as more support services were available and would benefit local officers who were currently drafted in to ldquobackfill for custody officers when they were on leave.It was not made clear whether the decision to take custody officers away from Dalkeith would see opening hours of the station reduced or changed.However, Ms Mertes stressed that the custody facilities would not close completely and would be available for major events in the area or times when it was felt they were needed.And she said that current custody staff based at Dalkeith would be given the option to transfer their services to support local policing.She added: ldquoIn terms of Dalkeith, should someone need to be brought in for an interview it will be open.ldquoThis is a flexible model that will allow us to push and pull resources into Dalkeith when needed.Concerns were raised about the additional journey time for officers transporting prisoners to St Leonardrsquos for custody however, Ms Mertes said that the benefits outweighed the disadvantages, pointing out that officers could sometimes find themselves manning empty cells at Dalkeith when they could be spending time on local policing.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, committee convenor, said that the move could prove beneficial to those who found themselves spending a night in the cells as well.And the decision was welcomed by the committee convenor to downgrade Dalkeithrsquos custody centre from a full-time operation to lsquoancillaryrsquo.He said: ldquoThere are some concerns that there is movement towards the centre of Edinburgh but there may be some benefit for the poor souls taken into custody.ldquoIf they are released from Dalkeith, getting back to North Berwick is an absolute nightmare, whereasthey are released from St Leonardrsquos, getting back to North Berwick is substantially easier.

title: east-lothians-jamie-ramsay-cycling-across-uk-80-days-drum-support-olympics
story: Jamie Ramsay had planned to travel to the international showcase last year, cycling and sailing the whole way from London to Tokyo.But the coronavirus pandemic saw the event pushed back  months, with Jamie, from Whittingehame, now going on a journey with a dference.It will see him complete  days of socially distanced cycling around the UK through June and July.The -year-old, sponsored by Whole Earth , said: ldquoIrsquom disappointed not to be able to go the whole way to Japan but am really looking forward to meeting fellow Team GB supporters in Scotland and around Britain.ldquoWersquore all in this pandemic together and need a bit of fun. I hope my passion and determination to do this challenge will get people in Scotland behind our Team GB heroes and show the benefits of exercise and nutrition on positive mental attitude and wellbeing.The journey will take Jamie ndash who has previously cycled from Sao Paulo in Brazil to Boliviarsquos La Paz, and run from Vancouver in Canada to Argentinarsquos capital city Buenos Aires ndash around Britain.The former Belhaven Hill, Stenton Primary and Loretto School pupil will pass through towns and cities twinned with or named after places along his original route, including Moscow in East Ayrshire and Holland in Hampshire.Instead of ending up in Tokyo, he will be crossing the finishing line in lsquoStokeyorsquo, also known as Stoke-on-Trent.Visiting Team GB athletesrsquo families, schools and fans en route, Jamie will record their cheers and waves on doorsteps, creating the biggest virtual Mexican wave to spur on Team GB hopefuls.His gruelling challenge will also see him climb Ben Nevis, cycle Hadrianrsquos Wall, and swim the Blue Lagoon in Abereiddy in south-west Wales.Last Tuesday, two-time Olympic rowing champion Helen Glover fired the starting gun from Londonrsquos  Queen Elizabeth Park to signal the start of Jamiersquos journey.Helen, who is aiming for a hat-trick of Olympic gold medals when the Games get under way in July, said: ldquoOur fans mean everything to us but wersquore now facing a Games this summer with no British spectators in Tokyo.ldquoJamiersquos epic journey to help get fans behind us is awe-inspiring. We have so much respect for his perseverance and hope hersquoll spur us on to bring gold home for our fans this summer.Follow Jamiersquos progress at wholeearthfoods teamgb wholewayjourney

title: north-berwicks-catriona-matthew-unveils-solheim-cup-sculpture-gleneagles
story: Europe edged out the United States frac - frac to win the competition at Gleneagles for the first time since .Now, a commemorative sculpture, created by Scottish artist Jephson Robb, has been unveiled in front of the captain and key representatives from Gleneagles, Event Scotland and PING Europe.Catriona, who won the Solheim Cup three times as a player, unveiled lsquoMatchrsquo last month.She said: ldquoTeam Europersquos victory on Scottish soil will always remain one of the greatest achievements of my career.ldquoIrsquom sure this wonderful sculpture will also remind the many thousands who visit Gleneagles each year of a truly exceptional Solheim Cup I will certainly never forget.Catriona, of North Berwick, is due to lead Team Europe again later this year as they look to retain the trophy at the Inverness Club in Ohio, with the tournament teeing off on August .Jephson ndash one of only a few Scottish artists to have work in the permanent collection of the prestigious Museum of Modern Art, New York ndash was commissioned to create a permanent sculpture as a lasting reminder of the event.More than , spectators visited the -acre Perthshire estate, a record attendance for a womenrsquos UK golf tournament.At . metres tall, referencing the average height of the competitors, the stainless-steel mirror polished sculpture sits atop a Scottish Whinstone circular plinth which is inscribed with the names of players, captains and assistants, and the final score.

title: modern-day-makeover-historic-ormiston-footpath
story: The path, known locally as Clarty Loan, links Park Road and Limeylands Road.It was once used by coal miners on their way to and from work at the four mines surrounding the village.It is now used by local residents as a shortcut to the local shops, park and primary school, and is also seen as a safe route since it is not suitable for vehicles.With new homes being built in and around Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association suggested that upgrading the path would be of great benefit to the local community and area.Walker Homes, which is building properties in the west of the village, agreed to fund the reinstatement of the path and pay East Lothian Council to do so.The improvement works consist of new lighting along the walkway.The issue of lighting along Clarty Loan was raised with the local housing partnership at East Lothian Council, which agreed to fund light installation.Mark Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association chairman, said: ldquoNow all the agreed work has been done and the path is looking fantastic.Peter Matthews, Walker Group managing director, said: ldquoWersquove worked hard to deliver a well-designed place to be enjoyed by families who live in the Long Meadow development and the wider village.ldquoAs part of our agreement with the council, we provided funds to ensure the path which runs along the side of the development was upgraded.ldquoAs a responsible developer, as well as delivering high-quality developments for our customers, wersquore committed to providing opportunities to enhance the local area and contribute investment to benefit surrounding communities.

title: traditional-tents-replaced-wooden-cabins-holiday-campsite
story: Scripture Union Scotland has been running camping holidays at Scoughall Farm, east of North Berwick, since the early s.Now, changes to the campsite will see five wooden cabins, as well as a pod, put in place of the tents.The charity, which uses the site from March through to October, runs ldquomulti-activity, resident events for young people.It said: ldquoThis change will enable us to meet the changing expectations of young people without departing from the historical style of the campsite.ldquoThe new buildings will be located in the same area as the tents were pitched and will allow the site to be used to its full potential throughout the season.ldquoThere is no plan to increase the capacity of the site or theof the season.ldquoThe buildings will be supplied with electricity by linking to the on-site supply or from small inidual solar units attached to each building ndash there will be no other utilities supplied.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the proposals last week, with no members of the public objecting to the scheme.The local authority imposed two conditions: that the accommodation can be used only from March to October, and only by Scripture Union Scotland or an organisation on its behalf.

story: The owners of The Mart, East Linton, were initially given temporary permission to use the restored building for events in  but the Covid- outbreak saw the approval lapse.Now, they have applied for the right to hold a range of celebrations in the building, which they acknowledge was not built to ldquocontain high levels of sound.And East Lothian Council has given them the go-ahead to host events until the end of this year, while restricting how often they can have amplied music or sound.The Mart owners applied for the building, which sits in the centre of a restored site with a farm shop, cafe and market stalls, to be given Class  status.That would allow it to host events such as birthday parties, weddings, christenings and baby showers.There are also plans to hold community events such as gala day at the building and hold film nights.But issuing its approval of the change in use, council planners insisted it could not have nightly noisy events.They added as one of its conditions that ldquono events involving amplied music and or amplied speech shall fall on consecutivedays.A former animal auction mart, the hexagonal timber building was built in about  and is Category B listed.Applying for the change of use on behalf of The Mart, Urban Animation said: ldquoThe Mart business has invested heavily in bringing the building back into active use, after years ofdecay and listing on the Buildings at Risk Register.ldquoIt is a Listed Building which has been restoredto the highest standard and is once again a valued asset to the Mart site and East Lothian.ldquoIt isnow essential that the building is able to operate as a flexible space, accommodating a moreerse and productive range of new uses and activities.

title: covid-vaccine-passport-scheme-announced-scotland
story: Those who have been vaccinated can download a letter from the NHS Inform patient website, or request a letter from the Covid Status Helplinethey are not online.But as details of the vaccination status scheme were announced, Scotlandrsquos Chief Medical Officer Dr Gregor Smith urged people to be "highly cautious about international travel"and ldquocontinue to limit their travel abroad.Only those travelling to a country where proof of vaccination is needed as an entry requirement should request a letter.There are currently no countries that require travellers to show their vaccination status, but the letter scheme is being introduced because international travel requirements can change quickly during the pandemic.If yoursquore planning to travel abroad, you must:Countries may move between the green, amber and red lists at short notice.You should not assume that a country on the green, amber or red list now will remain on the same list over the weeks and months ahead.Before you travelYoull also need to:While in Scotland, you must at all times follow therules on Covid-.Testing while isolating in your hotelWhile staying in your hotel, youll need to take a Covid- test on day twoand day eightof your  day stay. These tests will be delivered to you at your hotel.If either of these tests are positive for COVID-, you may need to quarantine at your hotel for longer than  days.The cost of isolating in a hotelTo isolate in a hotel, youll need to pay:Theres no charge for children under .If you need to stay longer than  days because youa positive Covid- test, or because you have been told you are a close contact of someone who has tested positive, you must book extra days through theCTM booking portal.There will be no charge for these extra days.If you have been in a country or area on the red list at any point in the  days before arriving in Scotland, you will only be allowed to enter theUK either:You should not travel to red list countries or areas on holiday, or for any leisure purposes.Before travelling to Scotland from a red list country, yoursquoll need to:On arrival in Scotland,you mustquarantine in the hotel yoursquove booked for  days. If you test positive for Covid- while in quarantine, you may need to quarantine for longer.If yoursquove been in an amber list country in the  days before travelling to Scotland, you must:On arrival in Scotland you must:Before travelling to Scotland from a green list country or area, you must:You will not need to isolate unless:the result of the Covid- test yoursquove taken on day twoafter arriving back in Scotland is positiveThe Scottish Government said it hopes allowing people to download their own documents will ease the burden on the NHS, as travellers will not need to ask their GP for a letter.As the vaccination programme progresses, digital Covid Status Certicates, which will include vaccination and testing data, will be brought in for international travel.Dr Smith said: "Given the risk of ing with infection, and especially of introducing new iants of the virus, we continue to be highly cautious about international travel."Everyone should continue to limit their travel abroad and while I understand the need for some people who want to reunite with family, when it comes to holidays my advice continues to be play it safe and staycation this summer."For those that do need it, this new service will provide people with a record of their vaccination status for outbound international travel."They should only access their recordthey are planning to travel within  days and it is a requirement of their destination."

title: gardening-five-easy-seeds-children-sow
story: "With the days hopefully warming up there is still timefor kids to get outside and try their hand at seed sowing," says Alana Cama, RHS schools and groups programme manager. "There are plenty of fun vegetables, tasty herbs and beautul flowers that can still be sown now to provide some tasty treats and bursts of colour over the summer months."Children can get a real sense of achievement from nurturing a plant from seed and its a brilliant way to learn about where our food and flowers come from."These five easy seeds to sow in late May or early June, are Camas top picks for making gardening childs play..... SunflowersLt spirits with this summer favourite loved by birds and bees. The flower heads come in a range of colours, from yellows to dark reds and oranges. You might want to pick a very tall iety such as American Giant, which can reach a towering height of around m."Sunflower seeds are large, making them easy for tiny hands to handle - they can be sown inidually in pots first and placed on a bright windowsill, or sown straight into the soil in a sunny spot. Sow them in May and keep them well watered," Cama advises. "Watch out for slugs as the seedlings appear and support the stem with a cane as the plant gets taller. Sunflowers take about - weeks to grow from seed to flower."Add a sense of excitement and keep kids interested by having a sunflower growing competition, involving your household or street," suggests Cama. "Or consider gting potted sunflower seedlings to friends and neighbours to brighten up their day.". NasturtiumsNasturtiums not only look pretty, they have edible peppery-tasting flowers that are great for decorating summer salads. Carefully sprinkle the large seeds into cm-deep drills made in the soil and then cover up. Give trailing ieties a go by sowing them in a container or hanging basket.Children might enjoy keeping an eye out for caterpillars of the cabbage white butterfly, which often munch their way through the leaves. These hungry caterpillars are interesting to watch and provide food for birds so its worth putting up with a bit of damage, Cama suggests.. Dwarf French beansPods of dwarf French beans can be eaten fresh from the plant or are delicious cooked up as a side helping of vegetables. French bean pods come in a range of dferent colours from green to cream and yellow to purple. Varieties include Cobra, Tendergreen, Purple Teepee and Purple Queen.This type of bean doesnt like the frost, so the end of May to early July is the ideal time to sow them outdoors, planted cm deep and cm apart."They grow to about cm tall so are best grown grouped together so the plants support each other. Another option is to collect twigs and push them upright into the ground to help keep the beans climb up and keep them off the soil. Remember to keep the beans well-watered, especially during dry weather," Cama advises.. Squash"Squash are exciting to growyou have lots of space and they come in a huge assortment of dferent shapes, sizes and colours. One even has flesh that resembles vegetable spaghetti. Varieties include Sweet Dumpling, Crown Prince, Honey Bear, Sunburst and many more. You could even try growing a butternut squash," she suggests.Squash have very large seeds so are easy for little hands and fingers to plant. Sow in late May to early June and only plant them outside once all chances of frost have passed.Squash are very thirsty so keep them well watered, especially in the drier summer months. It is also a good idea to give each plant food in the form of liquid fertiliser , to help them grow luscious green leaves and lots of tasty inidual squashes.. HerbsBasil, coriander and chives can be grown in pots on an indoor windowsill, so are idealyou dont have much space. Sow these small seeds in pots and watch as they grow."Our top tip is to use a seed sower or the palm of your hand to sow these teeny tiny herb seeds. You could even opt for something a little dferent and experiment with purple basil or garlic chives," Cama advises.For more spring gardening activity ideas and free resources for schools visit the RHS Campaign for School Gardening .National Childrens Gardening Weekruns from May -June .

title: pro-union-parties-indyref2-obsession-fuelling-debate
story: In part, this obsession has led to the SNP being let off the hook for its failures in government as was reflected in this weekendrsquos election results and perpetuated by every media outlet across the country zoning in on constitutional questions.Over the past few weeks, the majority of pro-Union politicians have used every sound clip offered to them to exclaim their anti-independence thoughts rather than explain how they propose to get this country back on its feet and how they could work with the Government to put recovery first.With all eyes focused on the constitution, it has worked in the favour of the SNP who have managed to be elected to Government with a record number of votes, despite their failings over the past  years in charge.The First Minister herself admitted during the campaign that she had taken her ldquoeye off the ball as Scotland racked up the highest drugs death in Europe. But there doesnrsquot appear to have been any rebuke for the drugs deaths crisis, their failed education record, missed hospital waiting time targets, rising child poverty rates, the exam results scandal, or failures in local policing.The next Scottish Government has an opportunity over the next five years to make amends for past failures and getting caught up in an independence campaign will only take the SNPrsquos eye off the ball once again.However, the SNP did not win a majority in the election and as a minority government will require support from other parties to pass budgets and any major reforms.The Scottish Greens will likely prop up the SNP in future policy discussions, but this will requirepolicy trade-offs infor budget support.With COP firmly in the sights of both parties as an opportunity to showcase Scotland as a leader in tackling climate change on the global stage, will the Scottish Greens be willing to lend support to independence which could risk the SNP taking its focus off meeting its emissions reduction targets of % by  ndash which it has done for the past two years in a row.They have already said they want bold action from the Scottish Government and now they are in a position to bargain for this.Read more:Indyref and a blinkered green agenda could harm Scottish farmings futureDuring Sundayrsquos Andrew Marr programme, a suggestion of next spring to hold another referendum was put to the First Minister, to which, of course, she said she was contemplating. Nicola Sturgeon hasnrsquot officially committed to a timescale, other than the first half of the next parliamentary term, but it would appear that the media is setting the ball rolling by proposing such a timeline. As much as I have criticised the SNP for pedalling talks of Indyref during a pandemic, journalists are also guilty of fuelling the debate and diminishing print space or airtime for more immediate and pressing issues.Over the past week I have been moving into my new house, which has involved many hours of deep cleaning whilst tuned in to my radio and coverage of the election.Hats off to BBC Radio Scotland team for managing to fill three daysrsquo worth of election coverage with very little to report on other than the one major news story: would the SNP gain a majority Although they covered results and reaction across the entire country, the main topic on every reportersrsquo lips was whether the SNP would have a mandate to hold another referendum. So, for every listener tuned in, we are being told that this is the discussion we need to be having, this is the headline we should all be taking away.In between googling tutorials on how to sand kitchen worktops, I checked in to the community Facebook page for my local village and was struck by the fact that none of the members were remotely engaged in discussions over the election, let alone independence. Like many other communities across the country, this village is still in the grips of a pandemic, so quite understandably, most posts and discussions revolved around Covid advice and best practice, information about the local youth club reopening, as well as a series of church services.Read more:Scottish election: Indyref cant continue to dominate the next five years mdash there are bigger issuesMembers were posting aboutfitness camps and slots which had come available for hairdressers and beauty salons. Local businesses desperate to rebuild and get customers in their doors.Economic recovery is what matters to so many, yet we are so embroiled in constitutional questions that we lose sight of the ramications the past year has had for so many businesses and iniduals who have lost their jobs and families living below thepoverty line.There is no denying the fact that there is indeed an appetite to reopen the debate around independence, the recent vote shows an almost   split down the middle, but I do not believe it should be up to the media to frame the discussion.There is a huge job ahead for the next Scottish Government to deliver on a national recovery and all opposition politicians and members of the press must be focused on holding them accountable for the measures they are taking to get the country back on its feet.Letrsquos not do Alex Salmondrsquos job for him by inadvertently holding the SNPrsquos feet to the fire over independence but instead hold their feet to the fire over the nationrsquos recovery from the pandemic.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: food-joy-eating-singaporean-food
story: Food: The joy of eating Singaporean foodElizabeth HaighThe trains that rattle directly above chef Elizabeth Haighs Singapore coffee shop clack-clack-clack down the phone line, while her neighbours appear to be drilling with total abandon. She shouts over the clamour nonplussed - all that noise means action, le ing, businesses reopening.Not that her Borough Market restaurant, Mei Mei, has been dormant through the last year. Opening just a few months before the pandemic completely shuttered bars and restaurants, Haigh quickly pivoted to takeout, meal kits, and feeding the vulnerable and local key workers.Speaking a few days before outdoor dining resumed in England, shes buzzed. "I cannot wait to share things on plates again Im sick to death of putting everything in takeaway packaging."Singapore-born Haigh, , trained as an architect before turning to food via a stint on MasterChef in . She went on to win a Michelin star while at Pidgin in Hackney. Now shes written her first cookbook, Makan, whose title means dinnertime, or lets eat. Haigh calls the book "a love letter to my family" and "our Singaporean heritage". Its packed with the Singaporean dishes she grew up eating , using seasonal ingredients found in Britain .In the book, she writes: When people move and mix together, food just gets better - and is adamant thats true, "because food represents community. And without community, theres no food, theres no recipes, theres no knowledge of culture and dishes."She says peoples interpretation of Singaporean food is often confined to Singapore noodles, which is nonsense. "One type of noodles in Singapore  It doesnt exist," Haigh scoffs. "[That is] a fusion of someones idea of Singapore."While high streets tend to be brilliantly spiked with restaurants celebrating Indian, Chinese, Thai, Indonesian, and Vietnamese food, Singaporean restaurants often just arent in the mix. "There are many great ones, but just not enough," says Haigh, and its that representation thats been missing.Partly its down to the exceptional culinary secret-keeping of Singaporean home cooks. "Makan represents the culture of my mum," explains Haigh. "She cooks a lot, like a lot of her generation, but they dont really pass on that knowledge because its just their way of showing love, that they do all the cooking."Haigh had to doggedly prise the knowledge out of her mum, but youll be glad she did. The recipes in the Nonya Secrets chapter, featuring her spiced chicken noodle soup, Gado Gado peanut salad, Malay hot and sour noodles, in particular are ones "she would go probably to her grave withshe could I had to beg her to share them with me".Telling her mum these very personal recipes were to be published in a book "took some convincing", but Haigh had a strategy. "I promised a lot of cooking - and a dedication." It was also important to her to be able to make these dishes for her three-year-old son, Riley, so he could share them with his friends. "Thats the way to get your mother, bribe her by using the grandson as leverage," she says wryly. "I just wanted it to be normalised, so its a cuisine everyone recognises more, and that he can be proud of."In a climate where Asian hate is increasingly making headlines, exacerbated by Covid, and attacks on iniduals and businesses are escalating, representation is again crucial. "Ive had that all my le, right " says Haigh of anti-Asian racism. "Im glad that everyones got more of a voice to stand up against it now, because its just not tolerable."If you normalise this style of cuisine and this food and people know more about Singaporean culture," she continues, "it [becomes] normal. Its just representation it really does matter."Unravelling and then recreating her mothers recipes was a challenge in itself though Haigh had to translate her mums ingredient guestimation and dismantle some of the internal scaffolding of her own classical French training, "building it back up again, as per how my mum wanted it to be". She hadnt previously needed those recipes sequestered in her brain. "Traditionally in my generation, not lots of Singaporeans cook," Haigh explains. "In Singapore, were absolutely spoilt for choice by hawker food. Its more common to go eat somewhere because its so cheap."The homesickness involved in not being able to travel or access that delicious, clamorous street food world, was another motivation for Makan, "to recreate those dishes and recreate those memories".Ask her what shell do the second she can visit Singapore again, and Haigh is instantly imagining taking a taxi from the airport straight to her customary hawker. "Ill probably be there with my dad, sitting at our usual table," she says. "Well order all the satays, and a bucket of beer. And probably some barbecue chicken wings - everythings on the barbecue. And they have stingray as well, which is wrapped up in banana leaves and a layer of sambal tumis belacan [a spicy, limey sambal sauce with fermented shrimp paste]. And its just absolutely ine. For me, thats heaven. It hits you in the face, that chilli is so spicy. The chillies in Southeast Asia are just another level of heat."The moment dictates the meal: "For Singaporeans, thats how we choose what we eat and when". Soyou need something hearty, itd be her Hainanese chicken rice business on" or a rendang. If under the weather, shed turn to noodle soups, and for celebrations, itd have to be Singapore chilli crab.Whatever the mood though, eating is paramount. Instead of saying Hello as a greeting, Singaporeans are likely to say, Are you hungry , or, Shall we get some food ."Lets cut out the necessities," says Haigh with a laugh. "Are we going to eat or not " Andwhoever youre with isnt planning on eating, then "its basically, Oh, are you gonna watch me eat "Its that delight - in eating, cooking and trying food - that Haigh hopes to bestow. "Im a feeder, just like my mum," she says. "I wanted to write Makan so much because I wanted to share that joy." And you cant not feel it in every recipe.Makan: Recipes From The Heart Of Singapore by Elizabeth Haigh is published by Bloomsbury Absolute, priced pound. Photography Kris Kirkham.

title: recipe-french-bean-toasted-hazelnut-salad
story: Ingredientsg French or runner beans- tablespoons extra virginolive oil cloves garlic, peeled and sliced dried chilli crushed tablespoon red wine vinegarBlack pepperHandful finely chopped flat leaf parsley handfuls hazelnuts or pine nuts, roasted for - minutes in a medium oven.MethodTop and tail the beans. Cook in boiling salted water for  minutes or so until tender but still with a good bite. Drain and refresh in iced water to retain their bright colour. Use a large frying pan. Warm the extra virgin olive oil and add the sliced garlic and chilli. Sauteacute for a few minutes ndash enough to flavour the oil.Add the drained beans, turn them in the oil to coat them well and warm them through.Add the red wine vinegar and warm for just for a few more minutes to allow some of the acidity to evaporate. Take off the heat and allow to cool. Crush the toasted nuts lightly and scatter them over the beans. Add a good grinding of black pepper and scattering of chopped fresh parsley. Serve fresh.Francescarsquos tarragon new potato saladThe leaves of fresh tarragon are packed with a distinctive flavour which is bestused sparingly.Ingredientskg new season salad potatoesBunch syboes or spring onions tablespoons extra virgin olive oil- tablespoons mayonnaise tablespoons salted capers soaked for  minutes and well rinsedFresh tarragon leavesBlack pepperMethodScrub the potatoes and, with the skin on, boil in salted water until cooked. Drain. Cut into quarters.Trim and wash the syboes and chop. Add them, the drained capers and the tarragon leaves to the warm potatoes. Dress with the olive oil and add the mayonnaise, mixing well to coat the potatoes. You can use only one of theseyou prefer.Season with plenty of black pepper and a good scattering of chopped parsley. Best served at room temperature.Mary Contini OBE is a writer and Director of Valvona  Crolla ltd.We are happy to welcome you in our CaffegraveBar and shop again, open all day.Book and order online: www.valvonacrolla Follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter.

title: agenda-must-change-culture-immigration
story: The Windrush Inquiry revealed how the hostile environment policy had caused people who had lived here all their lives to lose their homes and jobs. In response, the Home Secretary promised "a fairer, more compassionate Home Office". But instead this plan creates a two-tier asylum system: preferential treatment for the small numbers who can travel here through official refugee resettlement schemes, and harsher treatment for those who travel on their own initiative and arrive in the UK via third countries.Those arriving on their own initiative will only get a right to remain for  months be regularly assessed for possible deportation receive fewer benefits than claimants who arrive by approved routes and have "restricted" family-unication rights. This is demonstrably neither fairer nor more compassionate.Further, despite being called a "new plan for immigration" the proposal fails to address some of the long-standing problems in our immigration system.It does nothing to help refugees who become homeless those who must leave supported accommodation at very short notice and have no money to pay for housing.It does nothing to address the dficulties faced by asylum seekers in supported accommodation, some of whom have been put into very poor-quality hotel rooms and offered little support, sometimes with tragic results.And it does nothing to prevent destitution among those with "no recourse to public funds" who canrsquot get benefits, eventhey have been legally working here. In fact, it is likely to put many more people into that predicament.Encouragingly, throughout the pandemic, public agencies were able to use public health legislation to bridge the gaps in the immigration rules and ensure that many people had safe, secure housing rather than being forced to remain homeless.However, instead of building on this experience and giving public bodies greater discretion to support those at risk of destitution, this Home Office plan would extend the "no recourse" rule to anyone seeking asylum in the UK on their own initiative.This is the wrong approach. Time and again it has been shown that, with the right support, people can progress their immigration claims and regularise their status. Of the families with "no recourse" who were supported by UK local authorities last year,  per cent were granted leave to remain. People simply need a secure place to stay and some legal help to sort out their documentation to gain leave to remain in the UK.As we build an immigration system for the st century we need the right policies, better legislation, and a dferent culture. The Home Office said in responding to the Windrush scandal, we need to "see the face behind the case". However, this plan and recent events in Glasgow remind us that we still have some way to go.Callum Chomczuk is National Director, CIH Scotland

title: neil-mackay-ugliness-sectarianism-champions-downtrodden-really-scottish-values-2021
story: The notion comes with more than a hint of exceptionalism. The discussion is an especially hard one to have on these British isles of ours. To say Scotland has "dferent" values to England is either heavy with anglophobia, or weighted with inferiority.We donrsquot shy away from assigning dfering values to other nations, though. France and its muscular secularism America and its love of the gun Australia and its scorn for social class. Each example, however, is a stereotype. Not all French are secularist many Americans hate guns there are plenty of Australian snobs.Over the last week, two events on the streets of Glasgow almost demanded that we discuss whether Scotland really does have values which dfer signicantly to the rest of the UK: the protest against immigration deportations in Pollokshields, and the disgraceful scenes of Rangers fans rampaging through the city.Letrsquos deal with Rangers first. Itrsquos easier to address values we donrsquot like. What happened ndash the thuggery, violence, sectarianism, destruction ndash has been condemned across society. Itrsquos indefensible. It disgraced the country. But it happened, and itrsquos happened before. There may only be a few thousands of these people in Scotland, but whether we like it or not, theyrsquore what the world saw at the weekend. They project an image of Scotland. We cannot escape that in the eyes of others wersquore blighted by sectarianism, and the hooliganism and intimidation that always accompany it. To those watching from outside Scotland, what happened in George Square represents"Scottish values", just as much as the football hooliganism of the s blighted the reputation of England as a whole on the worldrsquos stage.Read more: Dark forces of sectarianism have come to exploit independence and the UnionThe horrible irony is that we here, inside our own country, know that the vast majority of us reject such behaviour ndash that only a handful of the population behave like this. Yet to an outsider, wersquore all tarnished with it. Just as all Americans are seen,wrongly, as "gun nuts", we here in Scotland are being labelled, wrongly, in the eyes of other countries, as a nation where bigotry prospers. Scotlandrsquos shame, indeed.We may define ourselves in opposition to events like these however,we mean that, then we must prove it. To validate that "value" ndash the idea that sectarianism has no home here ndash we have to stamp out the little fires of sectarian hatred still burning around this country. Jail is a good fire extinguisher for sectarian thugs. Crippling fines a good fire retardant for those in authority who fail in their duty to society.The events in Pollokshields also tell a dferent story of Scotland, in comparison to the rest of the UK. With sectarianism, we share baggage with Ulster in our broad attitudes to immigration, though, we seem quite alone. Nowhere  in Britain would have been the site of such resistance to the Home Officersquos "hostile environment" policy. When one thousand people on the south side of Glasgow compelled Border Force officers to back down and prompted police to release two of their neighbours set for deportation, a clear iding line was established between "Scottish" and "British" values.What happened last week in Pollokshields was not a one-off. This country has a proud pedigree of showing respect and care for refugees, as long opposition to dawn raids and Dungavel detention centre proves.And here we get to the heart of this apparently dfering value between Scotland and the rest of the UK. Scotland is unique among most nations, itrsquos fair to say, on the issue of immigration. Brexit at its heart was an anti-immigration vote. Brexit didnrsquot appeal in Scotland. We didnrsquot vote to close our borders against outsiders. Northern Ireland, which also voted to stay in Europe, was voting for peace and stability rather than expressing a pro-immigration position. A Pollokshields-style event is as unlikely in Ulster as it is in England. In UK terms, Scotland resembles those Democratic "sanctuary cities" during the Trump presidency.None of this is to say that there arenrsquot voters concerned about immigration in Scotland, or whorsquod like tighter restrictions. But immigration is ndash at least for the time being ndash a much less pressing political issue here than it is in England. Perhaps thatrsquos a legacy of decades-long dislike of the Tory Party, associated as it is with hardline anti-immigration policies. That antipathy may also account for Scotlandrsquos much more vocal opposition to austerity.Clearly, though, we also enjoy the luxury of opposition without responsibility. Itrsquos much easier to hate a policy when you donrsquot have to pass laws on it. Many Scots long opposed to British immigration policies, who also support the idea of an independent Scotland, have expressed worry at times thatwe ever do split with the UK, we might find our own liberal attitudes to immigration evaporating in some quarters.Immigration feels destined to become part of the constitutional debate. Only the foolish couldnrsquot envisage Project Fear II identying this social dference and exploiting the spectre of mass immigration.Read more: After the death of Mercy, Scots Government should break Westminster immigrationScotland is also at odds with Europe on immigration. France drts ever closer to the embrace of the far right and the lure of Marine Le Pen. The EUrsquos Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier, positioning himself for a run at the French presidency, said he wanted to suspend immigration to France, including family reunions. Germany without Angela Merkel may become a cold place for refugees. Italy has set a hard face against those seeking sanctuary.For the time being ndash in limbo as Scotland is, a nation without the powers of a nation ndash we can see that wersquore "dferent", although that dference offers both blessings and curses. Sectarianism, whether we like it or not, shows a Scottish face to the world. Kindness to the desperate and the downtrodden, to refugees needing support and friendship, also shows a Scottish face to the world.Perhaps, therersquos some comfort in that strange mix. Like all nations, we arenrsquot special or superior. We are in parts bad. We are in parts good. We are, like most nations on Earth, a shade of moral grey.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: andrew-mckie-end-summer-holidays-abroad
story: Of course, a substantial chunk of the British population has always had a taste for xenophobia, to the degree that quite of few of them are willing to apply it to fellow countrymen who happen to live more than a few hundred yards away. Even those free of this tendency, however, may be tempted to mull over what there is to be said for it, since there isnrsquot much abroad abroad, as it were.There is the exciting ldquogreen list of about  countries that the UK government will let us travel to, though thatrsquos no guarantee that the countries themselves will. But the choice is limited. You can go to St Helena, the South Sandwich Islands and the Falklands, but in Europe your options are Iceland, Gibraltar or Portugal.:Boris Johnson is right: the rules donrsquot apply to him, by Andrew McKieNo doubt more places will go on the list as we get towards the summer, but there will still be some people hesitant about the wisdom of piling into a tube of recycled air and wall-to-wall strangers in order to get to some country where, on the EUrsquos record so far, most of the population wonrsquot be vaccinated.The experience of previous rises in coronavirus cases after the Easter and summer holidays last year may also lead some to think that it will be safer to stay in the UK. And the fact that countries that chose to close their borders and keep their economies open, rather than the other way round, seem to have had better results may be one reason why the UK government is slow in reopening travel.Though they will be worried about the airline industry, the authoritiesrsquo chief concern is probably encouraging tourists from other countries to come and spend their money here, rather than worrying too much about whether we can go to Torremolinos or Ayia Napa to spend our money there.Even those of us who are enthusiastic travellers sometimes forget how very recent such journeys are for most people. Many of us have got used to the idea that good weather, major landmarks and decent food are readily available within a couple of hours, often with a plane journey costing less than the anorak yoursquod need to buyyou were going to spend the summer in this country.But itrsquos only in the last  years that this has been an expectation for many people, and only really in the past  or so, since budget airlines became commonplace, that it has been readily affordable for almost everyone. One of my grandfathers, born in the centre of Glasgow, never travelled any further than the Isle of Wight, and Irsquom not sure the other one ever left the country, either.Even when I was growing up in the s, foreign travel was still relatively exotic: I was well into my teens before I went as far as England, and my sole experience of abroad was a single trip to northern France. I was  before I had been on an aeroplane, and my impression is that that wasnrsquot especially unusual in those days.Yet by the time my own children were teenagers, theyrsquod notched up visits to at least a dozen countries, partly because taking them abroad on holiday was usually a good deal cheaper than going somewhere in the UK. Vacations in Cornwall, the Scottish islands, rural Wales or the Norfolk coast now have more social cachet than going to Benidorm, and a price tag to match. While wersquore at it, the word ldquostaycation, which is so ugly it shouldnrsquot exist anyway, can only mean staying in your own house while yoursquore off work going anywhere  in the UK is a holiday, just not a foreign holiday.The fact that the UK attracts nearly  million foreign visitors a yearsuggests therersquos plenty to do here ndash therersquos hardly an international list of top destinations that you ought to visit that doesnrsquot have London in the top three, but the sheer ersity of British landscape and heritage more or less guarantees somewhere interesting to go.If you can afford it. Presumably British rental accommodation, hotels and holiday parks will be even more expensive this year,people canrsquot travel abroad, or are deterred from doing so, either on health grounds or because they may get saddled with an unexpected and expensive quarantine requirementanything changes while theyrsquore away. Itrsquos possible this will be a lasting trend, too.Therersquos growing disapproval, especially among environmentalists, of cheap plane travel ndash in fact, ordinary le having been shut down comprehensively is, it turns out, exactly what some environmentalists want, and quite a number of them have been proclaiming how much better everything is without travel, traffic, cities, restaurants or shops.:Andrew McKie: What can Starmer do to save Labour But it is also true that the growth in travel in recent decades has been happening at a time when there is less and less necessity to do it. You can always bring abroad to you. There are countless books, internet material and television programmes about almost every corner of the globe:you really wanted to, you could probably find out more about Vientiane or Mombasa or Port-au-Prince in a few hours online than you would by going to those places, without any of the cost, discomfort or time involved.The collections of almost all the worldrsquos important museums are available indigital form. The most exotic foods are available in every high street: in the s, olive oil was a specialist ingredient now your corner shop will sell you kaffir lime leaves, plantain or zarsquoatar.Therersquos just one element that canrsquot readily be provided: sun. At this time last year, the strictures of lockdown, still a relative novelty, were offset for a lot of us ndash or at least, those with access to the outdoors ndash by uncharacteristically good weather. May  was the sunniest calendar month on record, with much of the country having an average temperature of F. Unless we get a repeat of that, perhaps the airports will be busy this year after all.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions.
